author: Steve Reynaud
bottom_line: Strong winds will continue to form slabs of unstable wind-blown snow along ridges and in gully features.  Unstable snow may still exist in some areas due to a previous buried weak layer.  Strong March sunshine may create areas of wet snow on sun exposed slopes.  Look for signs of instabilities while traveling in the backcountry and be willing to change plans if you encounter unstable snow.
hazard_discussion:
• Many natural and intentially skier triggered wind slab avalanches were observed on Mt. Judah, in the Donner Summit area yesterday.  Up to size D1.5.
  • Numerous avalanches in the size D1 to D2 range were triggered Monday by backcountry travelers on N to NE aspects in the Donner Summit, West Shore Tahoe, and Carson Pass areas.  At least two avalanches involved buried surface hoar.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Strong to gale force SW winds will continue through today transporting snow onto NW-N-NE-E-SE aspects in wind exposed areas.  Winds will slightly shift throughout the day to the W and eventually to the N tonight as winds start to decrease.  Wind slab avalanches are expected to occur today and could be up to size D2.  Wind slabs that receive large amounts of solar radiation may further weaken causing failure.

Look for clues such as recent avalanche activity, blowing snow, wind pillows, and snow surface scouring to determine where these wind slabs are forming.  Make a plan to avoid steep wind loaded terrain and areas below large cornices.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
A layer of surface hoar was buried on Sunday March 19 that was the failure layer in at least some of the avalanches reported this past Monday.  Multiple layers of graupel also exist in the upper snowpack with some still showing weakness with snowpack tests.  No avalanches have been reported since last Monday, but with continuous small storms, visibility has been limited and uncertainty continues to exist.  Additional snowfall over the last few days and today is gradually increasing the slab depth and continuing to provide stress to these weak layers.

Recent wide propagating avalanches, unstable snowpit test results, snow surface cracking, snowpack collapse, or whumpfing are all signs of unstable snow in the area.  If signs of instability exist, move to non-avalanche terrain with no steeper connected terrain above.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Intense solar radiation from strong March sunshine may occur today.  Depending on location, long periods of full sun could be enough to wet the snow surface and cause wet loose instabilities to form.  As the snow surface becomes wet, it's time to change aspects or move away from avalanche terrain.  Roller balls and pinwheels would be signs that the snow surface is losing strength, with larger wet loose avalanches entraining more of the recent storm snow becoming possible.
forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.
